{{Infobox figure skater |name= Melissa Militano |image= |caption= |fullname= Melissa Mary Militano |altname= |country= [[United States]] |formercountry= |birth_date= {{birth date and age|1955|4|26}} |birth_place= |hometown= |residence= |death_date= |death_place= |height= {{convert|153|cm|ft|abbr=on}} |partner= |formerpartner= [[Johnny Johns]]
[[Mark Militano]] |coach= |formercoach= [[Peter Dunfield]]
[[Ron Ludington]] |choreographer= |formerchoreographer= |skating club= [[SC of New York]] |retired= 1975 |medaltemplates= {{MedalCountry| [[United States]]}} {{MedalSport | Pairs' [[Figure skating]]}} {{MedalCompetition|[[North American Figure Skating Championships|North American Championships]]}} {{MedalSilver| [[1971 North American Figure Skating Championships|1971 Peterborough]]|Pairs}} }} '''Melissa Mary Militano''' ([[married name]]: Warkmeister; born April 26, 1955 in [[Rockville Centre, New York]]) is an [[United States|American]] [[figure skating|figure skater]] who competed as a [[single skating|single skater]] and [[pair skater]]. As a pair skater, she won the [[U.S. Figure Skating Championships]] three times, in 1973 with her brother [[Mark Militano]] and in 1974 and 1975 with [[Johnny Johns]]. Their coaches included [[Peter Dunfield]] and [[Ron Ludington]]. Melissa and Mark Militano represented the [[United States at the 1972 Winter Olympics]] where [[figure skating at the 1972 Winter Olympics|they placed 7th]] . Militano was also a talented singles skater. At the [[1970 United States Figure Skating Championships]], she became one of the first female skaters to successfully perform a [[toe loop jump|triple toe loop jump]] in competition, in a performance that won her the bronze medal in the junior ladies division."U.S. Championships", ''Skating'' magazine, Apr 1970 At the 1971 [[U.S. Figure Skating Championships]], she won the junior ladies title, again landing a clean triple toe loop."Nationals", ''Skating'' magazine, Apr 1971 She later gave up competing in singles skating to focus on pairs. Militano and Johns retired from competitive skating in 1975 and toured with [[Ice Capades]]. After her marriage in 1979, she had little involvement with skating for many years, but currently works as a part-time coach in [[Las Vegas, Nevada]]. ==Competitive highlights== ===Singles career=== {| class="wikitable" |- !
